paragraphs.text:
%md
# Variables
Scala has two different types of variables. The preferred and most commonly used actually is not variable, but can only be assigned with a fixed value upon initilization. Therefore these fixed variables are more like values and declared with "val"

result.msg:
Variables

Scala has two different types of variables. The preferred and most commonly used actually is not variable, but can only be assigned with a fixed value upon initilization. Therefore these fixed variables are more like values and declared with “val”

paragraphs.text:
%md
But since sometimes you need really variable variables, Scala supports these too. They are defined usign "var".

result.msg: But since sometimes you need really variable variables, Scala supports these too. They are defined usign “var”.

paragraphs.text:
%md 
# Types
In many cases, you do not need to care about the type of a variable, since these are inferred automatically by Scala. But of course, later when declaring functions and classes, we need to specify types. Scala has the following built-in primitive types:

    Byte
    Short
    Int
    Long
    Float
    Double
    Char
    String
    Boolean
    Unit
    Null
    Nothing
    Any
    AnyRef
    
A variable with a specific type can be delcared via

    val x:Double = 12

result.msg:

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Tuples

Tuples are very important in Scala and are used in many places.

result.msg:
Tuples

Tuples are very important in Scala and are used in many places.

t1: Int = 1
t2: (String, Int) = (a,12)
t3: (String, Int, Int) = (a,12,14)

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Functions
Of course every program needs functions.

def fn(x:Int, y:Int) : Double = { return 2.0*x +  y }

fn(23, 5)

res371: Double = 51.0

fn: (x: Double, y: Double)Double
res374: Double = 40.0

process: (value: Double, preprocess: Double => Double)Double
res398: Double = 22.0

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Nested Functions

In Scala it is possible to nest function definitions. The following object provides a filter function for extracting values from a list of integers that are below a threshold value:

result.msg:
Nested Functions

In Scala it is possible to nest function definitions. The following object provides a filter function for extracting values from a list of integers that are below a threshold value:

defined class Decorator

applyDecorator: [X](f: X => Int, decorate: Int => String)X => String

decorator: Decorator = Decorator@1f8e24a8

calculator: Int => String = <function1>
[46]

meter: String => String = <function1>
[12]

paragraphs.text:
val meter = applyDecorator((s:String) => s.length, decorator.decorate)
println(meter("Hello World"))

def my_abs(x:Int) = if (x > 0) x else -x

my_abs(3)
my_abs(-100)

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Break Statement

There is no such thing built into the core language. But it is available via the Scala Standard Library

result.msg:
Break Statement

There is no such thing built into the core language. But it is available via the Scala Standard Library
